FEV-dLneXWNlY15L8ts-fQ.text: Any place with a crowd as persistent and devoted as that at Tapas Brindisa must be doing something right.Full disclosure: I didn't order any of the mounds of incredible food I saw pass by me when I sidled up to the bar on a recent Saturday. I had quietly broken off from my vegetarian/vegan family for half an hour to come in and try the ham -- legendary ham, according to a London friend.I ordered a platter of charcuterie that could have kept four people busy, and a healthy glass of tempranillo. All the hams on the Gran Reserva list came from animals raised near the Portugal border, and fed a steady diet of acorns and chestnuts. (If the restaurant had mentioned  that the animals were serenaded with the Pan Flute every evening at sunset, I wouldn't have been surprised.)The jamon itself was stunning: buttery, salty, velvety, and profound, with an intriguing funk from years of aging in the Iberian heat. The chorizo was equally addictive -- with a chili heat, but only enough to warm the mouth. The tempranillo was a perfect match.While I snacked, I saw awesome-looking platters go by: steaks with eggs, patatas bravas, shrimp bathing in garlic butter. I'd advise any visitor to try all of them based on the sight and smell alone.

Jw4EOM6yjs6wuK06sn-1lA.text: I don't get it; People write quite favourable reviews about this place, but i wonder why. It's tapas, so you expect small portions, but the prices are in main course territory. The attached photo is for lamp chops. Admittedly delicious, but at nearly 10 pounds for two teeny tiny fatty chops, I'm not sure how the staff sleep a t night. Perhaps the reason they all sneak off to the kitchen is for a quick guffaw. Be prepared for it to be noisy, cramped and uncomfortable. We spent a comparative fortune, but we're off now to go and have some food as we're hungry. Tapas I get, but if you're charging main courses per plate, it just feels like it's starting to hurt when you sit down, if you see what i mean. Grrrr.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom

TgOI1EPvAm7Dz08WCUBQTg.text: Abismal service from some of the least happy people we have yet to encounter. They are doing you a favor when waiting on you.The food was quite average to boot. Definitely not worth the walk.

YJJQz9CrSmyGZSYjV_ikDA.text: Came to Brindisa on Saturday morning for breakfast by chance upon wanting to kill time at 10am and we were looking for a good and not super pricey place to dine.We walked by, took a glimpse at the menu and decided to see what else was open at Borough. The only other real sit down place was roast and at £12 for an eggs benedict we we obviously not sold. So back to Brindisa we trotted. I opted for the scrambled eggs, mushrooms and grilled tomatoes with manchego cheese at a modest £6 and the other half settled on their iberico ham with two sunny side up eggs and chips. Now we thought to also throw in an order of bread with lavender honey, but our waiter politely informed us of the portion sizes so we held back.And true to his word the portions were big...dare I say huge? I think it was because it was 10am and I'm not used to having mother feasts such as the one that was laid on the table before me. The mushrooms were cooked to perfection and what I sensed was a lovely garlic butter flavour. The eggs came on fresh sliced toasted bread and the slices of manchego was a tasty combination.I must venture back for the actual tapas menu as I've heard good things. But when in need of a hearty breakfast, Brindisa does not disappoint. I quite literally did not eat again until dinner time...

K4tE89i5rV-Gd0QRsbMZoQ.text: Here is my problem--I gave 5 stars to Barrafina which is my very favorite tapas place by far, so although I loved Brindisa it is not the LOVE I feel for Barrafina.I did enjoy Brindisa--stood at the bar and had a great bottle of wine (stemless wine glasses give it such a casual feel) and thoroughly enjoyed my plate of jamones.  We finally were able to get a table and had delicious squid, gambas, and spinach.  But I felt like I wanted the spinach coca at Barrafina and there isn't as much intimacy in the restaurant.  Still a fabulous choice in the hood and you can't go wrong here.  Sorry, Barrafina tiene mi corazon....

nsf55UW57IBUuI2twRR5YA.text: I had higher hopes of this place based on the reviews and kinda felt meh about the overall experience. The jamon is amazing and the wine selection was pretty good. However the tapas plates were just okay. I'm curious how this place would compare to say Jose which isn't terribly far from this location.

hC2evGpnNfNcndwPWARRTQ.text: Its been a long time since i have been meaning to write about my serendipitous visit to Tapas Brindisa. It is not too far from where i work and i came for lunch here with Gemma on one of her short notice visits to London.We wanted to sample as many of the dishes on offer as possible. We ordered four items to share. 1. Spanish omelette, one of my long time favourites. It had been cooked with generous amounts of onions and potatoes, and so was extremely tasty. 2. Hake. It was alright. I personally don't find much flavour in fishes that are merely boiled. This was surely not my favourite item on the menu. 3. Chorizo. Here they did really well. It was served with red peppers and toast. The best dish that we had, in my opinion. 4. Lamb cutlet. It contained quite a lot of meat. But we weren't given a choice on how it was to be cooked. It turned out to be a little more "bloody" than the cutlets that I am used to. With one drink, the price tag came to be about £20 per person. Given that I generally liked the food and that the price was reasonable, I want to go back. But they don't accept reservations. I did try to get a table one evening, but was scared off by the potential 2.5 hour wait. I hope I have better luck next time.

TNtmpEMdWIAf5ljhbbubQA.text: I like places where they are friendly and let you try things.  So a place where they let you gobble 4 different types of expensive jamon is pretty cool.We ended up leaving with 2 bags of jamon, some scrumcious blue cheese, quince jam, 2 types of great olives (and I don't even really like olives) and some toasted almonds.All in all, a great visit and I look forward to coming back for more.  The only thing was that the expensive ham was a bit lacking as it was right down to the bone and tasted well, frankly a bit shit.  At least there is something for next time.Yay!

8u0w4ItbSnNzCXzgk_BX9A.text: Okay now I know I'm a foodie and I think confirmation of this was that I went here with my best friend who I have now discovered, is not nearly as much of a foodie as me. I have been wanting to go to this tapas place for ever and every time I have tried it has been so full that we couldn't get a seat, I now know why!I ate so much meat here I think I actually left oinking! We had a lovely window seat and when our meat plate arrived I could see passersby eyeing up the piggy on my plate. It's not cheap but not so expensive that I had to pay with my grandma, any actually after the wine I drank I possibly would have paid with her!We left with bellies full of meat and wine, always a good thing I find!

Bd0mtYjGI-C8lAfVZ3YPkA.text: I have been to many places like this, they were all inside markets in Spain.  The only real differences being the clientelle and the prices. Their chorizo is superb, their jamon is superb, their queso manchego is superb.  Apologies for the reduced superlative set here, but the food speaks for itself.  If you like Spanish food, come here, if you have ever lived in Spain come for just a little taste of the things that you miss, if you have never been to Spain, come here,  buy the ham, buy the cheese, buy the chorizo and realise why you should go to Spain.

VUzIAKrWQnj4nGlQwra6JQ.text: Went here after a show at the Old Vic last Sunday. The atmosphere was lovely - really relaxed and friendly. The service was impeccable and the waiting staff were happy to advise on our choices (every time I go for tapas I get greedy and can never make my mind up!) Excellent sharing platters, large portions for a group of four of us and some absolutely delicious wine.You could tell everything was lovingly home-made and authentic too.

GCBSd9DuX8bzc9p-l46h2Q.text: I love tapas brindisa--they have very good food and a great selection of wine (organized in an easy-to-understand fashion).  Try not to go right before closing, though, as the service can seem a bit rushed.

21WzLf534hLnfbTr6P4AXg.text: First, this is one of my favorite areas in and around London. On a sunny day this is the place to go. I had lunch at Tapas Brindisa today.  The area is crowded, but not too bad. You'll find a combination of locals and tourists. Overall, not too annoying. I recommend a table outside if possible, the interior is cramp. My favorite dishes:1. Pan de coca - (why) I love bread and olive oil. The flat bread and tomato is balance and there is a little salt to tingle. (comment) The bread is amazing if you dip it into the gambas al ajillo. Definite order again.2. Gambas Al Ajillo - (why) I love the idea of olive oil, garlic, and prawns. (comments) prawns are a good size and dish isn't too bad. I think they can add more garlic and oil to the dish, but overall not too bad. Order again but would like to be spicier and more oil.3. Croquetas de jamon -(why) classic Spanish & idea of ham inside mash potatoes! (comments) the dish is tasty and not too oily and burnt. The croquetas are a good size and well fried. I would order these again.4. Tortilla de chorizo (why) eggs, potatoes, and ham is a good combination to eat. (comments) the dish was a little disappointing. The tortillas are all pre-made, so not as fresh as I like. You are serve a wedge from a larger piece. I would have preferred and fresh tortilla where the egg oozes after you cut into it.Overall opinion: I would definitely return and probably wouldn't want to wait too long for a table. This is not the best tapas in London, but I think the location and food are a good combination.

VgMwHMqLi8mPFnHKBTD5zg.text: My love affair with cured meats, cheese, and red wine continues. Brindisa is the sister-restaurant of the Borough Market stall known for its chorizo and rocket sandwiches (look for the line-up a mile long on Saturdays).  This restaurant also usually features a line as it doesn't take reservations and is usually crammed to the rafters.  It's a bustling place that serves up a wide variety of typical tapas: platters of Spanish cured meats, selections of cheeses, peppers, some seafood, olives... the usual.  And for me that was the most disappointing part - there was nothing unique or overly memorable about the menu, although the quality of everything we ordered was very good.  But unlike meals I've had at Barafina, Iberica or Dehesa (I still dream of Iberica's black rice and the chili prawns at Barafina) I can't recall any particularly spectacular dish from Tapas Brindisa.

yfTPo997JkBuXGqdrb5G4g.text: wonderful place! I have been lucky and got a table quite quickly both times I was there.The food is truly authentic!  I dont find tapas outside of spain to ever quite get it right!  Brindisa does a great jobthey source amazing iberico ham!  And the potatoes----YUMArroz con leche for dessert--one bite and I was transported back to Spain

R-AUavGn1L_88X3tXk7aVQ.text: It's been 8+ months since I've to this place, and I still dream about their chorizo sandwich! The Brindisa vendor at the Borough Market prepares the best sandwich I've ever had, hands down. It's quite simple--grilled chorizo, rocket (arugula), and peppers all atop a bap (bun) that's drizzled with olive oil. This is a must if you go to the Borough Market in London!

jPeka0qmn7SLnx5laDmXUQ.text: Location is good, just next to the london bridge underground station. The restaurant is small with few tables. Atmosphere is ok, nothing special, but it was too loud in the restaurant. The tapas were very delicious. We had 5 tapas for 2 people and each of us had also a dessert. The food and service was excellent. We paid around 75£ with a botlle of red wine.

9r1aK3CxS4BFFVow6tB4Ww.text: I cant believe I am the first to review this place!!! It is FAB!I had dinner with a hard to impress Scotsman with discerning taste..His words (imagine the lovely accent) "Great place. Good Food. I tip my hat"Relaxed - buzzy atmosphere, delicious tapas, decent wine selection..Happy daysEnjoy!

v4kPjFQkEsO3Qhvaj-lMdA.text: A perfect example of how great ingredients treated sparingly make a magnificent feast. Go here now, go early and get the gambas.

w8rfpWN3Tw_J59kwj74y3w.text: I had been wanting to go to Brindisa for some time, and when the opportunity arose for a boozy Saturday lunch after drooling at the food porn of Borough Market  I went for it.Sadly , It was very disappointing. The service was terrible and the food ok, and the most expensive lunch I've ever had for a few bits of ham ( it was iberico bellota) and some cheese. The wine of the month was excellent though and the coffee very nice.

Zpz1DsZyZbvR8q7o_7XHzw.text: Lovely Spanish tapas food, great quality, reasonably priced too. Gets super busy here at the weekends, it's right at Borough Market, but if you go on a Sunday when the markets are closed, the area is a bit quieter. Makes getting an outside seat in the summer easier.A great spot to spend an afternoon or evening sitting, eating, talking, drinking......ahhh recommend for sure!!

R1Es1we1bGdU92B90_lNlQ.text: Waited a 3/4 bottle of wine. Sat and enjoyed nice service while truly enjoying the paras Braves, grilled lamb and fillet steak were great! If I went again, I'd skip the tomato bread and leave it to the Italians;)

7DSqkS4Iq4x9-zGyEkv93A.text: So how's the original outpost of growing tapas juggernaut of Brindisa doing since I last visited? Not as well as I'd hoped unfortunately... Situated on the corner of Borough Market's southern corner, no bookings Brindesa was always a tough (and tiny) table to score, light wood interior filled with souls exiting the market laden with goodies, unable to wait until their home before sampling them. The unlucky masses would look on through the floor to ceiling windows and resolve to turn up earlier next week. A recent midweek trip to the neighbourhood let me pop in for lunch on one of the less screwily busy days for the restaurant before the market next door grunts into life on a Friday.The menu is still a organic shopper's wet dream, everything veggie sourced from the nearby stalls while meats and spices come from the Brindesa shop, hotfoot from the best suppliers in their Spanish homeland. The joy has always been that you don't want to wait until you get home from the market, mainly because what the kitchen can do with the same handful of ingredients is infinitely better than anything you could manage.We've been spoilt by Jose, and the jamon croquetas he now serves up on Bermonsey Street. Those are light, fresh and heaven sent, these lumpen cigars of gluey mash under a too thick oily carapace just don't cut the mustard. Huevos Rotos - broken eggs over fried potatoes and Iberico pork sobrasada - is unevenly cooked. Soft slices of spud seemingly decanted into a lukewarm serving dish, the egg just the wrong side of soft and the sobrasada, a thickly spiced tomato based sauce, huddled in one corner under a slice of waxen potato. A great idea, and one I'm looking forward to borrowing for an inevitably hungover brunch, but there's nothing here any reasonably home chef couldn't improve on. Sautéed chicken livers with an onion and caper dressing were fine, and well cooked. If I'd just taken a plate of that with a muscular minerally and obscenely dry sherry, I'd no doubt be hurrahing from the rooftops. Compared to a recent revisit to gracefully ageing Barrafina, the team at Tapas Brindisa have got some way to go to regain their crown. If you're in the area, nip round to Bermondsey Street and see what their old boss Jose Pizzaro is up to at his brace of eponymous restaurants, either one of them easily has the measure of Brindisa I'm sad to say...

wJfOWJts62XlukV2VSRQdQ.text: Imagine this: Saturday night in London. You are with a small group of friends. It's 9ish at night, places are hopping, AAAND you're hungry. So now what? We had no reservation anywhere (Hey, I live in a town that doesn't need reservations!), a few places ventured/asked/begged had, on average, slightly more than an hour wait. But then, there's Tapas Brindisa, says I. I checked the Yelp app, it's gotten great reviews! Don't fail me, Yelp!We got super lucky. They informed me on the phone it was an hour wait, but if we came over fast, like a few minutes quick, there was a group about to leave and we could fill the spot. No, they don't take reservations you get here or you're screwed. Yes, it was pissing down rain that night, too. RUN BITCHES, RUUUUUUUN!!We made it! Success! And it was totally worth it. The place is intimate. We were a group of five and our seating arrangement was tight, but not uncomfortable. We sat next to other people but I never really heard their conversation all evening. If you start to feel claustrophobic just remember: vodka makes you love EVERYONE. Between the five of us we ordered about 12 dishes, maybe 14. Everyone ordered two (and we shared) and only a few people opted for dessert. We didn't have one bad tapas plate. They were all delicious. I especially enjoyed the creative pieces, like fried goats cheese with honey, and chorizo potatoes. We vacated when they were closing up. Also, do keep in mind that in London they will charge a 12.5% gratituity. You can ask them to remove it, but that's entirely up to you. You do get the death stare if you ask for them to remove it. I HAVE NO SHAME. (don't worry I added a small tip, GAWD).

pmZ88u3GX_shASYsn_qIog.text: Wonderful cold meats as you would expect and nice generous portions too with a nice variety for you to work around.  Great tapas and great wines, and given the name and location prices are good given the quality you get.  Of course it usually packed so not a place to come for a slow paced relaxing meal,  it it's hard to beat for genuine Spanish flavours.  It's a place where the people really respect the ingredients which is a very nice antidote to the overly fussy food for fusses sale.  Not to say that plates and flavours are not complex here, but the ingredients here really do sing.

3pKOm8oOoqjR2OH32XZgzQ.text: Good food, good price and fast service! This review is based on my breakfast experience at Tapas Brindisa. We went here because were looking forward to enjoy fantastic food around or in the Borough Market. Gladly our expectation was met and hunger satiated by Tapas Brindisa. This place offers breakfast menu which is much smaller than their regular menu but I must say it is deliciously well proportioned. I devoured those tasteful chorizo paired with eggs and potatoes while the mister had manchego cheeze, mushrooms, grilled tomatoes and eggs. We gulped down fresh orange juice along with our breaky! Yummy! I am happy happy happy for less than £20! Cheap date? Nah, just a sucker for a tasty food.

Jj2qpKEvsIIRjIzSMx7vjw.text: Wonderful meal and experience. A must if you're visiting London! The lamb plate is something that I still dream about...all the way from NYC... Yummy!

wSTBGhxWNnZFogenfCcymA.text: A tapas restaurant that nestles itself nicely between casual and classy. It'll always be busy here, not only because of its location in Borough Market, but because it carries a reputation for excellent food and a huge wine selection. And the reputation is deserved.We waited at the bar on a Sunday evening for 15 mins or so before being shown the table. The food menu is long, but neatly divided into types of food and even regions. I wouldn't normally think to order a fillet steak for a tapas meal, but it was fantastic; served on bread with onion chutney.Other highlights were the spinach, the chorizo and the croquettes. I'd love to come back here again, if only to try some more of the wine list!

C1C2ebYceqNZpxsfrcQrRw.text: I've since been back here a couple of times and I still really like it but a couple of the other dishes - tortilla and croquetas weren't quite as delicious. I am enjoying working my way around the menu though!

faToUmC31pXRA7Q61rkj7g.text: Went there on a Saturday morning, 10:00am, by chance visiting Borough Market, spotted a free table and in. Turned out is is really a nice place, excellent breakfast, english with a spanish touch - e.g. Chorizo instead of breakfast sausage and manchego for the scrambled eggs. The coffe is a delight and made it in my best coffee list: Hernandez & Wells, Monmouth and Jamie's Recipease. Service is very friendly, no rush even though the place was packed.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom

ncb-QbZddNB-iD5k92FgMg.text: Fast, efficient, great service, good ambiance and flavoursome dishes.

0uSTLKI8z3J6-t4ZNbOjvg.text: Great atmosphere, best tapas I've ever had....,I would have given 5 stars, but they seated us 45 mins later than they agreed. Still had a great night, but please be honest about how long your table wait will be

PyXp_60_ExuCShFYrAyZuA.text: I'm lucky enough to be able to get to Brindisa in about 15 minutes from my bolt hole in South London and its always a pleasure when someone suggests it for lunch or dinner (not a great place for solitary dinning in my opinion as it's a little too hectic). The no booking policy works well but means that given its position on the corner of the market and the fact that its very well known you need to get there early on a Saturday or linger about outside because the bar area is always full. In fact I'm beginning to think I might actually prefer eating in the bar area this summer - there are a couple of settings in the window which are quite quiet if you fancy something more intimate and the high stools by the door are nice and cool and give you a good view of all the action. Wherever you manage to get seated it's going to be cosy. Anyway yesterday was a light lunch to get us in the mood for a wander along the Thames and some retail therapy. B ordered up the clams with bacon and capers, the secreto iberico pork, tomato bread and a couple of glasses of the house white. Everything was excellent but the pork was just sublime - really well seasoned, full of flavour and cooked with a very skilful touch. The menu here is really well thought out and there is hardly a dish I would not think about ordering. I think the key is to order food to suit the mood and take it from there - I often see people over ordering so I'd advise taking it easy and order a couple of courses at a time as you won't be rushed to vacate your space. The punters are what you might expect in Borough Market. Plenty of foodie locals and tourists with an interesting smattering of randoms. The breakfast menu at the weekend looks great but you need to get there before 11am - I live in hope!!

L4BbS71isfRp2lXHO_c6Pw.text: I had high expectations of this place and decided to take my mom here for dinner since she hadn't tried Spanish food yet.  Though it was good, I can honestly say I loved Jose way more. It was really loud and crowded on a Wednesday night but we were able to be seated quickly. We ordered the croquettes, which were the highlight for me. Padron peppers, also good. The tortilla was a huge disappointment as well as the salad we had. Maybe I will go back to try it out again but for now, Jose is my fave spot for now.

ngYsoN_3EWFLPHGpJuR5xg.text: It is a love affair. The wait and time apart may be painful, heart wrenchingly so, but the reunion is always playful, passionate and steeped in goats cheese and honey.I started eating at Brindisa many years ago and it was my first real London regular. Nestled on the edge of the bustling Borough markets it was the place that I would always end up, my culinary home. It is very New York esque in its business model, they don't take reservations, if you get there after 7pm on a week night expect a 2 hour wait. I use to bide my time with several pints of Franziskaner outside the pub on the opposite street corner, did I ever tell you I love street side drinking?The menu is revolving, unpretentious and simplistic, mirroring the decor, food and staff, however there a few mainstays including the aforementioned goats cheese and honey. It is blissful, lingering and seductive, Monte Enebro goats cheese, flash fried, drizzled in honey and topped with crispy heart shaped beetroot chips, scrummalicious. My other regulars include the Chorizo Tortilla, rich and heady and the country toast with Alioli, slightly charred delicious brown bread with an Alioli so rich in its oliveness. The prawns in garlic are a must, don't let them take the dish when finished as the garlicky prawny oil is delish, smear it on your face and bossom and revel. The padron peppers are simplicity at its finest, lightly fried in olive oil and sprinkled with sea salt.  If you are feeling flush order some Joselito, I cannot roll my R's, but f**k I love this ham born from sweet nutty little acorn fed pigs its the finest on this planet.In summary, go there, drop your guard and if you don't like it well F off.

nrgRLqBNjjPEMcrfboT_vQ.text: This is a great place which serves up some delicious Spanish Tapas. The staff tend to be very upbeat and entertaining and definitely add to the appeal of the restaurant. I would say that this is the type of place which is great if you want to pop on for food after work or a trip to Borough Market as it gets very hectic and noisy and perhaps not for those who are after a quiet meal.  The tapas menu is good with lots of options - I went along with a couple of friends and  ordered a range of different dishes which works well if there is a group. Despite the place being busy we only waited 20 minutes for the food and it was lovely.Brindisa also has a stall on Borough Market at the back of the restaurant which offers a good range of authentic Spanish ingredients such as tuna loin - yes, it is rather expensive but the food is worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom

eQzz1G9lIjyvICQ8XJgYKg.text: Randomly stopped for lunch and glad of it!  Deep fried monte enebro was stunning.  Still thinking about it a week later. Huevos Rotos very good too.  Fantastic menu.  Would go back next time in London.

RdH21BQfk8zmSZ5dW_DMbA.text: Just turned vegetarian so probably not the best place to come, however found the few dishes without meat in the menu. All extraordinarily good, the dishes especially salads were perfectly balanced and it was some of the best Spanish food I've ever tasted. Fantastic wine and good service - a memorable afternoon and no pressure to move on (though we sat down at 3pm on Sunday so not peak time).

09Dq6j3OSbWQvIvyzK00Dw.text: There is just something fun and easy about Tapas. There are a few Brindisa restaurants around London, (and a Spanish food market at Borough Market), which keep Spanish food alive and well in London. Brindisa is one of the better examples of Spanish cuisine's favorites. And, when at Borough, it is really hard to pass up their tasty and satisfying chorizo sandwiches sold outside of their market shop. Delicious!

AKsqO7cnu8DSaSGCXbXWrQ.text: My husband did a little homework on a good tapas restaurant in our area, and we were not disappointed! This restaurant was excellent and clearly a local favorite. We waited close to 30 minutes for a table for 2, but it was worth it! Awesome staff, from Spain, and the food was excellent! I wish I could say we would be back, but sadly we live across the pond.

aF7VPPCymXq1GTFL_wpIvw.text: Excellent tapas place, the house specials were the most interesting (black rice with squid, and huevos rotos). The vegetable section is amazing too in this restaurant. Wouldn't go for the presa Iberica next time (pork was nice but think the least special item we've ordered on our visits here and at £11 I'd rather spend it on some more chorizo or charcuteria).

tmbmAvjg2KoYNqPrXt7d6w.text: This is a crazily busy place at anytime, which is a testament to the food quality. Fantastic tapas which arrives as and when it is made. Some dishes took a bit too long, but ultimately they were worth the wait. The staff are all very friendly, help you with the menu and provide a great service. Would definitely come back.

oWtwj0X0-C8_JcXyurGL1g.text: Hadn't eaten at a tapas place for several years before this visit, so I was filled with anticipation before stepping through the door. It was rammed in there (you're unlikely to be able to reserve a table such is it's popularity). But you can grab a drink at the bar whilst you wait for your table (45 min for us, bit longer than we'd have liked, hence the loss of a star).Anyway, the staff were a friendly bunch (even enduring my friend's attempt at speaking Spanish to them - cringey). We each ordered three dishes from the menu, there was plenty to choose from, but we stuck to the less than £8 dishes (some were upwards of £20 each).It started arriving in waves - my favourite format for being fed - and each and every one of those dishes was utterly delicious, a mouth-watering welcoming assault on the tastebuds.The two bottles of Rioja Zarabanda were also enjoyed (they were about £20 each).So all in all, a relatively expensive meal for a northerner, but it was totally worth the money, it just needs to be a bigger restaurant to seat more people quicker!

-5PAmjYQ8tTQMup0rc4s3A.text: Had lunch here on 11/6/2014Great and unique wine selection.  Tried four different red wines by the glass.  All were delicious!For food, we ordered the clams and beans, iberico bellota chorizo, patatas with alioli, and grilled pork loin.  Totally off the hook delicious!

8j3UDwg_fAU7bZ5vSC9SQw.text: A friend brought me here saying that the Tapas were great. I have to agree. This was by far the best Tapas I've ever had including several restaurants in Spain. We had a variety of plates including garlic prawns (Mmmmm.... garlic!) and even simple croquets that were the tastiest I've ever had. It was all delicious. This is a place worth seeking out if you are in the London Bridge area. We walked here after drinks at the Shard.

-Z_eIo7ZHVLcIcy6Q8jMNg.text: definitly recommanding this place! the atmosphere is great , very busy , people are really enjoying their time there.The staff is very good, friendly and professionnal.the food is surprisingly very good, as i am not super fan of tapas . they have a secret recipe : quality of their ingredients! bellota ham, patatas bravas, tortilla chorizo, it all taste fabulous. The tapas, some good vino tinto and your friends and you will be sure to have a pleasant moment.putting 4 stars ( only ) cause the cheese selection  is pretty poor & expensive.

qlOWl0xucYormwbbU51vzA.text: Great if you want to pop in for a quick bite and sit in at one of their high chair/tables. Food is good, nothing outstanding and the dishes seem to match what you would normally expect at a tapas restaurant. Prices may be a little overpriced. They do serve a really good coffee. (Visit - 03/06/2014 Lunch)

3OiIad3IUSHA7ou1bW7h0w.text: So when my friend suggested this place I had no idea I had been to the Shoreditch counterpart. Was so happy though when I realised I was in for another top notch meal.I haven't eaten better tapas to be quite honest. The wine was delicious and the atmosphere was buzzing. The service was attentive & friendly without being over-bearing.HAVE THE CROQUETTES! Sorry for the caps, but I'd blame myself if you went and didn't order them. Other delectable choices were the chicken livers, black rice & garlic & chilli prawns.Delish.

6YsukEkLVYwN1GanB3hplw.text: We ordered appetizers, but we didn't make a good choice. Potatoes were spicy which is not an issue, if they would have mentioned in the menu or at the moment of the order. Not impressed with the choice available on the menu or with the staff.

3aWVGJuHe_FyKr7c_8WeDg.text: Just a few words on this place. GREAT COFFFE and excellent service! We did have a few problems with our food. But the manager was great about it!

NhZm63KuZOpLBh9bys9I4Q.text: I am a total tapas monger / snob (I even have a list dedicated to tapas in NYC, that is how much I love them), so I can say with great conviction that Tapas Brindisa will not disappoint your palate!Came here on a Saturday afternoon around 2-3pm to meet with some friends and the place was relatively busy, but had zero effect on the level of service we received.  Our server was really personable - entertaining to say the very least!  He was definitely on top of things, keeping the wine flowing and the food coming!  Most notable dishes were the chili garlic prawns, fresh goats curd and the lamb chops.Go.... you will not be sorry!

Gr6B_V4zkX4M8E_1RaTz4g.text: Been to this place for the first time last night. We were looking for a Spanish restaurant with good accessibilty in terms of public transport.The restaurant doesnt offer reservations so we had to wait for a while, which is ok with a bottle of red :)The place has a lively atmosphere and was a bit loud. And it looks a bit basic at first glance. The service was quick, very friendly and the food was delicious! The tapas are good in size, you might want to order two or three for each person. I recommend this place.

_mT4iJ--SXj_WGZXux3SEQ.text: Poor service, not even comparable to fast food service.  They keep asking and pushing you but indeed keep missing orders and request.

MeS8I7dp-OPnWvFJPSgoEA.text: The best Tapas I have ever had!I can't fault this place. I met a friend for lunch here. The waitress who served us asked were we wanted to sit and we chose a table by the window which seated 4 but there were only 2 of us and she didn't make a fuss. The wine was lovelyService was very good Food was very yummy Would definitely recommend it!

Lq69t4us2kAjzn1ePNlwbQ.text: Fully booked so we reserved a table and went and had a drink for an hour; came back and waited 35min for them to sort our table out despite continual promises it'd be 2min.The food was OK, really nothing as special as the reputation would have me believe.  The vegetarian selection was very poor, overpriced and the portions tiny.  Most of the tapas were £8-10 and were the sort of thing you'd pay no more than £1-2 for in Spain.Despite all the buzz about this place I won't be returning.

x-uHEew9o1YO71bceABCyA.text: I had dinner here on a weekday evening with a friend, as we were looking for a bite close to London Bridge station and this is known to be one of London's best Spanish restaurants. We arrive at 7:15 PM and were quoted a 1h to 1h30 wait, for which we could either wait in the restaurant or leave and come about after an hour. The bar was crowded at the time and there was no room to stand against the counter, so we decided to go around the corner to Vinopolis for a drink before returning. We came back around 8 PM and were seated at 8:10 PM, so just less than one hour! We ordered the pan con tomate, Brindisa cheese selection, iberico de cebo ham, artichokes with truffle oil, croquetas de jamon, and fillet steak. The server asked how we would like the plates to come, and we asked for the first three together, which were more like appetizers, and the second three as main courses. The pan con tomate was surprisingly nice, not just your typical tomato spread but actual chunks of tomato on top. The iberico ham was extremely generous, with at least 10 slices on the plate, layered over each other and there was plenty to go around. We had four types of cheese on the platter, with 3 slices each for the hard cheeses and some soft cheese options as well. They were ok but nothing spectacular. The croquetas were my favourite main, and we got four of them, all of very large size. The artichokes must have been artichoke hearts and had a consistency of a root vegetable, but with the truffle flavour, it was of course still delicious. And the fillet steak actually comes served on bread, with cheese melted on top, and I kinda thought the cheese/bread mix tasted like what you find on French onion soup. Overall, this was a lot of food for two people, possibly too much, but it was a spectacular meal.

A6JC-mmVsuH4WyOP7SZk3w.text: Had Breakfast here on a Monday morning; the Scrambled eggs with spinach, this came served on sourdough toast, ordered a side coffee alongside. All very tasty, staff are friendly, only downside to the place is the lack of wifi.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccino
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Scrambled Eggs with Spinach

MOW0ywsOCsJ4RHKLW0CyMQ.text: Tapas Brindisa is a cute tapas bar in Borough Market.  The dishes are flavorful and the service is speedy.  While I love the ambiance of Brindisa and the surroundings of the hustle and bustle around the market, it is not my favorite tapas bar in the London Bridge area.  It is quite good, however, and convenient and for that reason, I would return there to dine.

FpQOCv0xqgH_vRrmd9ARug.text: {insert Not Impressed meme here}I'm obsessed with tapas.  It's like Spanish dim sum and you get a little bit of everything without feeling like a fat mofo.  At Tapas Brindisa, I thought I was back in Spain.  And I mean Las Ramblas in Spain, the tourist trap mecca of lukewarm microwaved Spanish food.Maybe I'm being harsh.  But in either case, I don't think the 2 hours I was told would be the waiting time for the next table would be justified.  We were immediately offered a table outside though, and at 7 pm on a semi warm (unlike our food) Thursday night, we eagerly took it.Tortilla de Espinaca £4.50 was mushy and cold, Huevos Rotos £5.95 and Patatas bravas £4.00 lacked the crunch the dishes usually have, Escalivada £5.95 was unappetizing and salty, £6.80 Black Rice was very very oily.  Salchichon de Vic £5.00 and the Pan de Pincel £2.80 were probably the best which is sad when the bread and sausage were the only things that stood out.I'm going to be searching for a better tapas restaurant, but in the mean time, I'm going to say I can't understand the hype here.  It's something when my favorite part of the experience was our hilarious eyepatched waiter and not the food.

8B8OdXkRx2DDkvjp1fxdHA.text: I came here on a Friday night and there were no tables so we stood around the bar and ate, which was a little unorthodox but worked well. We shared a range of dishes, the best of these was the ham which although very pricey was worth every penny. The food was so good that it reminded me of places in Barcelona. I will definitely come back, the only problem will be finding a quiet time so that I can get a table next time.

jitllGPPp_e4zPPwJA9UNA.text: Honestly the location is amazing... Huge sun trap with outdoor tables. Forewarning- I didn't eat here and that's what everyone does, apparently! But between 4 of us we drank over 200 pounds of booze all afternoon. Bottom line the service was brutal... I think because we didn't order food the waiters ignored us? They were busy talking to friends, looking around... Looking around everywhere except at the customers... It got so bad it was funny. The location means they don't have to try that hard! Would I return, yes because I also like the location!

01RVqEtlVMHmCFEQQnhWZA.text: I was a bit disappointed on my last visit. Every dish was super salty. It is a nice space, close to Borough market - would recommend for some small tapas over a glass of wine but I won't be going back for dinner.

HkYlBmUJSOPAqdhcGB6dtQ.text: Stopped here for lunch and food was just meh, service was ok but not very friendly. Was disappointed because it was recommended in Borough Market and we could've eaten at any number of places there.

R0HtGSAOT2zk-HkCTjiA6w.text: We went on Thursday night, which was clearly banker night (everywhere was heaving and we had to wait an hour for a table). I had been to the South Kensington restaurant before, though, so I knew it was definitely going to be worth the wait! We put our name down and came back 45 minutes later.True to form, we got a table just over an hour later, which was a huge relief after standing in the crowded bar! The service was attentive and the restaurant was small and loud, but the menu looked great!  We ordered LOADS and didn't regret it! Highly recommended are the pan de pincel, garlic and chili prawns, patatas alioli and the padron peppers (unfortunately I think these may normally be overlooked, but they are really tasty, little green peppers drenched in Maldon salt). We also had the chorizo board, which was yummy, but at £20 felt a little overpriced.I had a bloody Mary, which was quite full on, so I couldn't finish it, my only addition would be if they did virgin versions of the cocktails for those of us who are less inclined. Having considered that, I'm sure they would've done one if I had asked!

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Chorizo board (came with bread)
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. All the food!

-H_QPkXmyEMgncHNd86QzQ.text: Super nice staff. Most of them are Spanish speakers. Very nice tapas. Loved the bacalao, the padron peppers, and the charcuterie platter (with real Serrano hams). Too bad the terrace is a bit too close from a high traffic street.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom

KFCueMwe-xK81CXErdfJiw.text: My girlfriend being Spanish suggested we try a Spanish restaurant tonight in the Area of London Bridge. Was a little reluctant due to eating so much Spanish food at home. Anyway we were sat by the window but not at a table it was kind of sit at the window seal job and they just put your plates of food on that, "the window seal that is" Could not get your legs under anything but there was no big issue with it. The food came out very quick and I have to to say it was extremely tasty. Now some might see this as picky but I am a picky person and notice the little things, after all it's the little things that go a long way right. My partner started to order her food and ask the waitress in English if she spoke Spanish. "Si" said the waitress so anyway my GF starts to order hers and my food, not a word said to me by the waitress. I did feel a little Left out lol, we Had our yummy food then asked for the bill the lady comes over walks between us and was having a full on conversation with my partner for what felt like about 10 mins about life in Spain and so on but the problem was her back was to me the whole time truly her arse was in my face as she was standing in the middle of us. Now I don't know about anyone else on here but I would take the time out to try involve both people in the conversation if I was speaking to one person in a party of 2 and if I could not I would never have my back to them, rude I say. Would have been 4 stars if not for that complete blankage and almost 10 minutes of back staring I had to do while the lady who could speak English spoke to my GF. LOL.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom

rxd5DKxborEAdkfv7oaSWQ.text: Came here due to the good reviews.Well well well. The standards of reviewers these days has took a nose dive hasn't it. Maybe this was their first trip outside the local kebab or dominos.The food here was disgusting. Alioli was inedible... Looked like some sort of STI discharge. Octopus salad overdone and way too much acidity. Lamb cutlets for £10 were tiny and unseasoned. Patatas bravas not spicy at all and covered in aforementioned Alioli discharge.Disgusting, tasteless tourist trap food.Not cool.

UnJ1VNKWvfZbz0Tm6iAB_A.text: Visited London and came along this place with some co-workers. The tapas is very savory and interesting, in a good way. The inside is kind of small, but they make use of their surroundings very well. I would definitely give this place a shot if you're in the area.

ky4oAQkN1gMqiCBUhg-T-A.text: I ordered the Galician style octopus, tomato salad, and croquetas de jamon.  Four stars because everything was very good but not amazing. The octopus was well done, wonderfully tender, and flavorful. I was impressed with this dish.  The tomato salad was also quite good. Very fresh tomatoes.  I was less impressed with the croquetas de jamon.  They were a little too soft on the inside for my taste, even though they were nice and crispy on the outside.  By the 4th one, the texture was getting a little monotonous.  Service was pleasant and friendly.  Overall, I've had better food for about the same price, but it was still quite tasty, satisfying, and flavorful.

egZaJaTjORFOz5nLLfGS9g.text: I first went about 5 years ago (around the time I began to go out to slightly better restaurants) - I was dazzled by the upscale yet unpretentious atmosphere and general buzz this place has. Food is bordering on expensive but it has great wine (served in stem-less glasses) and an authentic feel. Small sharers I loved - padron peppers and the goats cheese with honey.

qMBmSFRQGPzND2UeFZMpcw.text: Ok, so no reservations. So what? Just go when no one goes (which might be never, during the holidays, because the Borough/Bankside area has evolved into a wild evening hotspot for drinkers and foodies alike). You would've still struck a good deal in terms of what you get for the money you pay. I always start with the Huevos Rotos (I've been advised that's what the Iberian natives do). The prawns are always fresh and adequate, a tad bit garlicky (I never understood why par subtle seafood like prawn must be smothered in garlic) but nevertheless a good eat.The croquetas jamon are so much fun, but then I've had very few bad experiences with these. Brindisa gives them an added touch of perfection.The squid ink risotto at Brindisa is still one of my favourites in London. The ink feels fresh and almost aromatised right for adequate flavour infusion into the senses. Neither too squidy nor too inky (if you know what I mean).Overall, while Brindisa might be snubbed when the connoisseurs benchmark it to the likes of Barrafina and Moro, it's still one of the better value for money tapas bars and definitely offers one of the best experiences in London. So two thumbs up for this one!

oPkfPyjK6A_3GNuHSWg--g.text: Meh.The food was good, but nothing was great. Service wasn't the best, but they were swamped.Come here for the ambiance if you're into noisy pubs.

rLpNPfzaAp17LKvvPPCd6g.text: I love tapas and the various flavours. Sometimes though you can get ripped off on prices. Not here though. Excellent food and flavours and great sherry a meal for 2 for £50 in this area of London (or indeed any area!) is good value. The atmosphere and the ambiance is young and fairly hip. Despite the fact that I am neither I really enjoyed the experience of this restaurant!

rHirwemAlX9iYwlyn4GzXQ.text: Food arrived cold. Small portions of okish food. Personally had better and much cheaper at chain restaurants! Bill came to £75. Really not worth it. Definitely not going back

cUcqSNIb-g5R3h9gQg3VgQ.text: My friend Lyn just happened to be in town with her bestie for a couple of NIN shows while I was in London, and as I trust her opinion more than the majority of people, I made a point of meeting up with her for dinner.  Definitely glad I did.Right next door to Borough Market (where they also purvey many of their meats), it's in a prime location for the after-office hours crowd, which makes for excellent people watching.  Get there in time for happy hour and you'll have a great time with plenty of sangria and a lot of food and still have enough in your budget for a visit to the pub.I love me some white fish, so I had a double helping of the boquerones, and of course you can't come here and not try some of their excellent charcuterie, but the nicest surprise for me was the black rice dish.  Savory, rich and decadent are the adjectives that come to mind when I think about it.  I am, in fact, drooling as I type this.

IGmsCD93dGJhVv8ABfmOEw.text: Service was terribly slow. It took forever for us to get our order in and the waiter kept leaving and saying he would be right back.Food was average but the one item we liked quite a bit was the Grilled Smoked Chorizo on toast. Smokey and flavorful on some crispy toast.They do not take reservations so the wait can be long. We came on a Saturday afternoon and it was packed with an hour wait.Grilled Smoked Chorizo on Toast with rocket and piquillo pepperPatatas Brava O Alioli fried potatoes with spicy tomato sauceCroquetas de Jamon Cured Iberian Ham CroquetasGambas Al AJillo Chili Garlic PrawnsBraised Oxtail

EOD48Ddo1hJrdR7Vp4XPRg.text: Went on Saturday night to try their 10th anniversary menu at 2004 prices. It looks like organised chaos, they don't take reservations so you need to go and leave your name on the list, which is controlled by one person who isn't easy to find as she does a multitude of different things at the restaurant. Once you have found her though, she takes your name and you're free to leave and come back. We were told a possible 45 minute wait, but on coming back half an hour later, they were preparing some tables. While we were waiting, a couple sat down at an uncleared table and were quickly turfed out by a waitress. The male turfee was quite loud and rude to the staff but was handled with professionalism and eventually left.We got a range of dishes both from the standard and anniversary menu and they came as follows:Tortilla with Chorizo - easily the best dish of the night, really tastyBroken eggs - little overcooked, the eggs having baked solid - they'd been described as still runny over fried potatos.Padron peppers - salty and oily but with great flavourGrilled lamb chops - nicely marinated and grilled well, but a little expensive for what was on the plate.Finally the spinach. Now this was a problem. Firstly we had to ask twice about the dish, and it turned up when we'd pretty much finished our meal, it doesn't take a lot of time to cook, especially when described as lightly wilted... Secondly, it didn't taste of anything, just a bit of oil and the raisins that it was mixed with. Finally and worst of all, it hadn't been washed and was full of grit. To be honest I had a mouthful and had to rinse my mouth out. We left it behind.4 out of 5 dishes were good, but that last one let them down completely. The waitress didn't say much when we complained about it, just that there was probably just a little left by accident.Not sure I'll be back, or at least, I'll be more careful with my selections.

Z5Hilv3eFVocDUd3zYkFmA.text: My favorite place to eat when I'm visiting the Borough Market. I love the Chilli Garlic Prawns, the Huevos Rotos, and the green salad. The vibe is warm and welcoming, a great place to pop into to escape a chilly London day. Enjoy with a glass of Rose Cava. Perfection.

VzAK9eP_psvsVdilYkTH1Q.text: In London for the day, I couldn't resist the temptation to try out Tapas Brindisa in Borough. A late call to arms to London Yelpers got me a great dining partner in the lovely Tirthankar D (Tapas is always better shared, right?) and we met up for a quick lunch on Thursday.It is not possible to make a reservation here so I made sure I arrived on the dot of 12 and it was easy to secure a table. The restaurant did fill up fast though so I would definitely recommend getting here early. A glass of Tempranillo, served in a tumbler not a wine glass, was a nice starter while I browsed the menu that is split in to many sections - picoteo (small bar snacks), tapas plates, charcuteria, cheese, bread and house specialties. We decided to choose four dishes to split between the two of us - Spanish tortilla, smoked chorizo on toast, grilled lamb cutlets and pan fried hake.The Spanish tortilla was traditional in style, being large in size and full of potato and onions. It was a great accompaniment to the rest of the dishes. The smoked chorizo was served on toast with roasted red peppers and rocket - a delicious dish, but then I am a huge fan of chorizo. The lamb cutlets were very full of flavour and cooked perfectly for me, but maybe a little pink for some people. They were served with a homemade portion of aioli (garlic mayonnaise). My only complaint would be that they were a little on the fatty side. The hake was served with potatoes, onions, fried garlic and paprika. The fish was white and fresh but I feel that if you are going to serve fish with the skin on, it should always be crispy, not flaccid and a little slimy!!The service was definitely more focused on efficiency than friendliness, a far cry from tapas bars in Spain, and even my local haunts in Brighton. I would have preferred a more authentic feel to the service, but I guess this is the price you pay when you come to a restaurant whose main focus appears to be getting customers through the door.I would definitely come back though, there are numerous dishes that I still want to try, and the beauty is that you can stock up on ingredients from their nearby delicatessen in Borough Market and try to recreate the magic at home!

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom

-aXbdjfjgIl9zh2agXVMXA.text: We went there as we were kind of late for the market and padella was crowded with people. It is a lively place. Lots and lots of people inside. Super loud. Me and my partner are not loudest people around so the conversation wasn't easy. On the other hand it did make me think of Mediterranean. Food was good. Small plates of tapas. Do order at least 3 per person as they're not super big. One that blew me away was not a chrorizo thing or some fish but cold and vegetarian mix that I cannot remember the name of and cannot find on the menu. My companion liked it quite a bit. Oh one neutral thing I can say is that bread that we were given in addition was just ok. I'd have hoped for more tbh.I probably won't visit it again due to the loud atmosphere and not very memorable food. Now that I think of the food there again I also don't remember anything spectacular. I guess I do recommend it but not without reservations. I'd feel bad for rating it a 3 but I feel 4 is little high based on my experience. If you like tapas and are all into that atmosphere then you'll definitely enjoy it a lot. Especially go with large group of friends then the experience will be greater with great variance of tapas.

mj3Ctq_M_A63V_CW-1fgXw.text: We hardly ever go to a place twice when on vacation but I loved this restaurant so much I insisted we go back on our last evening in town.Favorite dishes:Shrimp in oil, the sauce was soooo good. We ordered this both nights because it was our combined favorite. Bonus, get some of the bread to soak up the leftover sauceLemon chicken was tender and flavorfulOctopus over black rice (this was a small portion for the price but still very good)It's a great location, just off of Borough Market. Both times there was a wait but it wasn't very long.

rlieZmh3izMlksdDkDkN8w.text: We had a very quick dinner stop and thoroughly enjoyed everything. The prawns in garlic oil was one of the best I had ever had. The croquettes were fresh and flavourful, and the chorizo dish was filling as well. Given this was intended to be a quick pit stop, we didn't order much else, apart from side bread. We enjoyed dipping it away at the garlic oil from the prawn dish. Service was prompt and good. Despite it being busy on a Friday evening, they were quick to seat us (without a reservation) and to bring out all our orders. Ambience was good fun. Nestled close to Borough Market and right outside of the London Bridge tube station, it is one of the most convenient locations for a quick tapas fix.

uG0VuPzEdeJVFqtMyyS9kg.text: This place is SO much fun--and delicious.We ate outside on a pleasant September evening. (A space heater made it even warmer and more pleasant.)We ordered a range of tapas and every one of them was delicious. Plus, we had a flight of three sherries ("A Taste of Jerez") which definitely added to the experience. Service was efficient and the prices less than I'd have expected for a restaurant in such a busy, tourist-filled location.

pbx16iHUxAeHKq_VIBxXhQ.text: Brindisa is a lively and authentic tapas restaurant located in the heart of Borough Market. My friend and I arrived on a Thursday evening and waited for around an hour. They don't take reservations here, so be prepared for a queue during peak hours.Of all the dishes we ordered, I enjoyed the black rice the most. Its texture was superbly smooth, complemented by the crunchiness of the fried squid. A close second were the Padrón peppers, simply grilled with just a dash of sea salt.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Monte Enebro (7.95) - artisan goat's cheese, orange blossom honey, beetroot crisps
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Chuletillas de Cordero (12) - lamb cutlets, alioli, fresh herbs salad
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Escalivada (6.50) - roasted aubergines, peppers, onions, olives, coca bread

h6MjsBlqWygeBid7o1wLoQ.text: Brindisa is a causal authentic tapas restaurant by the Borough Market. There is a bar in the back and tables are quite to one another, the atmosphere is rather warm and lively. Great for a group gathering, but if you are into intimate conversation. Here might not be the place because your " neighbors" 2.5 inches away can definitely hear the details hahaa :)They don't take reservation here, so be prepare for a queue during peak hours. I would say an hour is quite common. I highly suggested to get drinks from the back bar before your name gets called up and chill ! If you don't have the time and mood for it, this is probably not the place.Every time we ate here, it has always been a great meal. Our usual orders including the Galician style shrimp, Squid Ink Risotto, Sea bass, tomato salad, and the most traditional tapas such as Patatas Bravas and croquetas de jamon. We also tried the meat dishes, but I would say the seafood dishes are more in my taste preferenceService is hit or miss here, perhaps it's a busy fast paced causal restaurant.  Overall, we love to come by after going to Borough Farmer's Market. Brindisa is definitely the best choice for tapas in Southwark/ Bankside. I always have a good time here whether I came with family or friends or a date.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Eat your Veggies Kids ;)

HYDY9HEZPyjoRgwlPfcanw.text: This place has an awesome selection of tapas that were all delicious. I highly recommend the patatas bravas and croquetas de jamón.

lTlO7LAlEWK8nXhYjpS7uw.text: After looking at the menu we debated waiting a few hours until we could get a larger group together. You can go wrong with this menu, I dare you to try. Turns out we couldn't wait and were stuck ordering tapas for 2 which made the selections incredibly difficult. To keep from fighting we left it to a social media poll to help us order.

72H3tQXTTy8_xNvylvSVAw.text: The food is amazing and the choices too. We went at about closing time and they still served us. The plates were rushed a bit. Ice cream was brought before we were done so we had to rush before it melted. If you are visiting from outside the UK you might find the prices a little pricey. However, I believe that the food is totally worth it and the service is great too. I don't like to give five stars but the food is that good.

EUPhsY33eLafVInAMNcZsA.text: Small portions, dirty tables, the food is ordinary and not tasty as it can be. Disappointed and left the place hungry and not satisfied.

l-evPuXFsO6Z9UMNTIh0NQ.text: I don't know how I can accurately describe this restaurant without my mouth beginning to water. I came here on a weekday morning before the Borough Market opened to kill some time. We were there for about 1 1/2 - 2 hours just hanging out and enjoying the food. It's a tapas/breakfast establishment and I got breakfast and an americano. My eggs were cooked to perfection and the chorizo was outrageous. It wasn't too spicy but had a good enough kick to it. I remember eating the chorizo and thinking to myself how this is what a chorizo should taste like. Definitely one of the better tapas restaurants I've been to, if you are in the area and want to check out a new different place, I would absolutely suggest you come here. Only pitfall was that the service wasn't all that great.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. My perfect americano
Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Eggs & spicy chorizo

EIbQzNj_xmr9HwmZsSEZpg.text: Great tapas, friendly service. We lamb, prawns, walnut salad and several other dishes. The music fits with the environment and the ambience is good thought a bit loud.

8iyZvubntCdmCHlTZSL9jA.text: Proper patatas bravas (paprika based instead of tomato sauce), great jamon and very good tortilla! Perfect place to have some Spanish tapas!

HLyroR_o_bmJU8WNJodXBg.text: Overpriced for overall lack of taste and portion sizes. Real disappointment. Most menu items are roughly $13-15 pounds and you're not getting much bang for your buck. Also, the waitstaff is a bit standoffish and they tell you off the bat that your time for eating at a table is restricted to 1.5 hours. I would pass and enjoy something else in London.

3WYpomgz-SRMZz_uE0Ggmg.text: Service was a little weird not sure if it's because we were foreigners or what. We went for breakfast which apparently is rare since they are most known for their lunch. However got the mushroom egg scrambled with toast which was cooked well lacked a little salt (American taste buds) but none the less cooked well Also got the potatoes and meat which reminded me of corn beef. And last but not least the pancakes....not a fan of the pancakes at all. Wouldnt recommend them at all, has no real flavor, and  one big mushy mess.

_MiuDTX7aomuvDnKZ09mpg.text: Excellent selection of quality Italian products to take home.Some hot food in site as well.Staff very knowledgeable.Ask about the different kinds of dried pork legs, you'll learn some really interesting stuff.

photos.caption: Photo of Tapas Brindisa - London, United Kingdom. Towards the end of Borough Market off Stoney st. Look out for the dried chillies hanging on the door

OZpKGwgET48_AIEQgzKd7Q.text: Do not go to this place! It's so overpriced and charges you for 4 small pieces of bread and water while bringing them to your table without even asking, which in any restaurant I've been to, it should be free. Totally a ripoff!

EKAqj71qg3iRLG2Mzx07zA.text: I was invited here for business lunch so I had nothing to lose and we could check out what these guys had to offer.The potatoes and the fried ham and cheese were average. The filet steak was definitely a step in the right direction and really tasty but my favourite order was the sea bass. THAT was very good and I enjoyed it a lot!
